verb.description: Cease to support or look after (someone); desert.
examples: her natural mother had abandoned her at an early age

verb.description: Give up completely (a course of action, a practice, or a way of thinking)
examples: he had clearly abandoned all pretense of trying to succeed

verb.description: Allow oneself to indulge in (a desire or impulse)

noun.description: Complete lack of inhibition or restraint.
examples: she sings and sways with total abandon

phrases: The boat started sinking and we all had to abandon ship.
For an hour her crew fought to save her before the order was given to abandon ship.
A fire in the engine-room spread to the hold, causing the crew to abandon ship.
Submarines were supposed to surface and give crews time to abandon ship before sinking their vessels.
All the ferry's passengers and crew had been ordered to put on life jackets and prepare to abandon ship.
origin: Late Middle English: from Old French abandoner, from a- (from Latin ad to, at) + bandon control (related to ban). The original sense was bring under control, later give in to the control of, surrender to ( abandon (sense 3 of the verb)).
